tossups.answer: LAPD [or City of Los Angeles Police Department or equivalents; accept Rampart Division or CRASH or Community Resources Against Street Hoodlums before read; prompt on police department or cops or similar]

answers: California [or the Californias or Las Californias; accept Alta California Nueva California or Baja California Sur or Territorio Norte de Baja California]
bears [or ursids; or osos; accept brown bears or California grizzly bears or Ursus arctos californicus; accept Bear Flag Revolt or Bear Flag Republic]
Eureka [prompt on “Queen City of the Ultimate West”]
parts: Name this provincia interna of New Spain that was scouted by Juan Rodríguez Cabrillo’s voyage on the San Salvador. El Camino Real connected 21 Franciscan outposts in this province, like Carmel, Soledad, and Santa Inés.

Mexican vaqueros drove the California subspecies of this animal to extinction. Alta California was declared an independent “republic” in an 1846 revolt named for a flag that depicts this carnivore, which California still flies.
The celebrity mountain man Seth Kinman shot hundreds of bears around Fort Humboldt near this large coastal city. The 1848 Gold Rush inspired the name of this redwood lumber port on Wiyot land.

answers: Aphra Behn (The second play is The Rover.)
English Restoration [or Stuart Restoration; accept Restoration drama or Restoration comedy]
John Dryden
parts: Name this author of The Emperor of the Moon. A play by this author, which was based on Thomas Killigrew's Thomaso, depicts the amorous adventures of Florinda and Hellena at Carnival.
Aphra Behn was employed as a spy by Charles II during this period of English history. William Wycherly and William Congreve were other authors from this period that followed the Interregnum.
This other Restoration author wrote about the Great Fire of London in his poem Annus Mirabilis. This poet also satirized the “true-blue Protestant Poet” Thomas Shadwell in the mock epic Mac Flecknoe.

answers: Clapping Music
magnetic tapes
trains [or equivalents like locomotives; accept Dif erent Trains] (Honegger’s piece is Pacific 231.)
parts: Name this piece, which features a 12/8 time rhythm being repeatedly shifted every eight or twelve bars until it returns to its original form, in an example of its composer’s characteristic phasing technique.
The composer of Clapping Music, Steve Reich (“RYE’sh”), used loops of this medium in his compositions It’s Gonna Rain and Come Out. This magnetic medium was used to record audio on cassette.

A piece by Reich titled for Dif erent examples of these objects is scored for string quartet and tape. One of these objects is musically depicted in the first of Arthur Honegger’s (“oh-neh-GAIR’s”) three symphonic movements.

answers: codes [accept code-switching; accept elaborated code or restricted code]
socioeconomic class
r
parts: Name this term which, in an unrelated usage, was classified into “elaborated” and “restricted” types by Basil Bernstein, based on the extent to which communication using these things makes underlying assumptions explicit.

Bernstein posited a correlation between exposure to elaborated code and this status, which he then linked to gaps in verbal IQ. People with a low type of this socioeconomic status will sometimes hypercorrect their language use.

A study by William Labov (“luh-BUV”) found that department store clerks in New York City adjusted how they pronounce this letter based on the class of their clientele. Non-rhotic accents like Received Pronunciation often omit this letter.

answers: calipers [accept specific types such as vernier calipers or dial calipers]
gears [or cogs]
go AND no-go gauges [accept in either order]
parts: Name these high-precision measurement devices. A common type of these devices features a scale with one fixed jaw and one moveable jaw, with the readout representing the distance between them.

Jaw motion causes a caliper’s dial to rotate via a rack and pinion, consisting of a linear and circular example of these devices. The number of teeth on these devices determines the mechanical advantage of “trains” of them.

To check a component against a known tolerance, these devices may be used instead of a caliper. These gauges are named for the fact that one must pass and the other must fail for the component to meet the specification.

answers: innate immune system [or innate immunity]
viruses
opsonization [or word forms like opsonize]
parts: Name this component of the immune system, which is often said to be more “primitive” than the adaptive branch it is contrasted with.

An important component of innate immunity is interferon, which is released in response to infection by these subcellular agents. Because these agents must infect cells to replicate, their antigens are presented with MHC I.

An important component of innate immunity is the complement cascade, which produces C3b that performs this process. In this process, a foreign cell is coated with immune proteins to “tag” it for phagocytosis.

answers: Portugal [or Kingdom of Portugal or Kingdom of Portugal or Reino de Portugal or Portuguese Empire or Império Português; or Portuguese Overseas or Ultramar Português; or the Portuguese Colonial Empire or Império Colonial Português]
Cape Bojador [or Cabo Bojador; or Rā's Būjādūr; or Cap Boujdour]
sails [accept lateen sails or velas latinas; accept square sails or velas quadradas; accept the Age of Sail]
parts: Name this kingdom that employed the Italian sailors Antoniotto Usodimare and Alvise Cadamosto. This kingdom traded cinnamon and pepper through Antwerp after it captured ports like Sofala, Kochi, Diu, and Malacca.

Portuguese explorers mastered the “volta do mar” navigational technique to pass this cape in modern-day Western Sahara, which presented a formidable barrier to the galley ships crewed by Vandino and Ugolino Vivaldi.

To pass Cape Bojador, Portuguese caravels employed this technology’s “square” and “lateen” forms. This ship technology often had a rigging named for Bermuda during its early modern “age” after the Battle of Lepanto.

answers: shepherds [or shepherdesses; or sheepherders; accept herdsmen or equivalents; accept ganadero] (The novel is La Galatea.)
Don Quixote [or The Ingenious Gentleman Don Quixote of La Mancha; or El ingenioso hidalgo don Quixote de la Mancha]
Rocinante (“roh-see-NAN-tay”)
parts: Name this profession. Members of this profession named Elicio and Erastro travel to a wedding in the first novel by Miguel de Cervantes.
Cervantes incorporated pastoral literary tropes into this other novel about an “ingenious gentleman” who travels with his squire Sancho Panza and mistakes windmills for giants.

After they fall in with a group of shepherds, Don Quixote and Sancho get attacked by Galicians when this steed of Don Quixote tries to mate with their horses. This horse’s exhaustion parallels Don Quixote’s old age.

answers: Sufi orders [or tariqa; accept Sufi brotherhoods or Sufi sects or similar; prompt on brotherhoods or orders or sects; prompt on Sufis]
pilgrimages [prompt on journeys or equivalents]
whirling [accept dancing or dance or equivalents; accept whirling dervishes; prompt on dervishes]
parts: Name these groups whose history is recorded in their silsilah. The Tijaniyyah group of this kind is active in West Africa.
The Grand Magal, a tradition of the Mouride (“moo-REED”) Sufi brotherhood, is an example of these events. Other Islamic examples of these events include the Umrah and the Hajj.

Another notable Sufi order, the Mevlevi, practice this action as a form of dhikr (“thicker”), the Sufi remembrance of God. The sema ceremony, which features this action, inspired a common name for the Mevlevi.

answers: drums [or drum set; accept Drums of Passion; prompt on cymbals; prompt on percussion]
5/4 (“five-four”) [or quintuple time]
Brown [accept Oscar Brown Jr. or Clifford Brown or Clifford Benjamin Brown]
parts: Name this instrument, which Olatunji played on We Insist!, an album by its player Max Roach. Roach pioneered bebop styles on this instrument by using a four-beat pulse on the ride cymbal rather than the bass.

The opening track on We Insist! uses this time signature to depict the whip of a slave driver. Paul Desmond wrote a song in this time signature for the album Time Out, which became the best-selling jazz single ever.

The slavery-themed lyrics of We Insist! were written by a lyricist with this surname. Roach led a quintet alongside a trumpeter of this surname, who was eulogized in Benny Golson's song “I Remember Clifford.”

answers: MALDI [or Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization]
mass spectrometry [or mass spectroscopy; or MS]
TOF analyzer [or time-of-flight analyzer; accept MALDI-TOF]
parts: Name this ionization technique developed by Hillenkamp and colleagues. This technique uses an absorptive material to stabilize large molecules, frequently biopolymers.
MALDI is used as an ionization source in this general technique, which categorizes molecular fragments by m-to-z ratio, allowing the determination of chemical species.

MALDI is often combined with this kind of analyzer, which can use a reflectron or an ion gate. This type of analyzer works because the velocity of an ion accelerated in an electric field depends on its mass-to-charge ratio.

answers: syllogism [accept word forms like syllogistic argument]
soundness
inductive arguments [accept word forms like induction; accept inductive logic or inductive reasoning]
parts: Name this deductive argument in which a conclusion is drawn from two premises. The statement “All men are mortal, Socrates is a man, therefore Socrates is mortal” is a classic example of this type of argument.

If both of the premises of a syllogism are true and the conclusion must be true as a consequence, then the syllogism has this property. Many fallacious syllogisms arise because they do not possess this property.

Syllogisms are examples of deductive arguments, which are contrasted with this type of argument that generalizes conclusions from specific examples. Proofs via this type of argument are sometimes used in math.

answers: Tepe [or Tepeler; or variants like tappeh or teppe; accept Göbekli Tepe or Tepe Yahya or Tepe Guran]

parts: Give this word that, like “höyük” and “tell,” refers to archaeological hills or earthen mounds. At a “Potbelly” site of this kind in Anatolia, Klaus Schmidt identified pillars carved with wild animals as an early temple.

Iranian sites like Tepe Hissar, Tepe Sialk, and Tureng Tepe provide evidence about the transition from this period to the Chalcolithic. Many Mesopotamians adopted settled agriculture in this prehistoric period’s “revolution.”

Hajji Firuz Tepe and Godin Tepe preserved Neolithic residues of this product, which Greeks held in the rhyton and kylix. Zhāng Qiān (“jahng-ch’yen”) possibly brought this product to Hàn China, which had previously made only báijiǔ (“bai-jyoo”).

parts: Name these events. In a 1992 novel, the Indian sapper Kip becomes disillusioned with Western society after he hears about how these events devastated Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

The bomb expert Kip appears in this 1992 Michael Ondaatje (“ahn-DAH-chee”) novel, in which the heavily-burned adventurer Almásy lives in an Italian villa that is constantly threatened by World War II bombing raids.
In this other Canadian novel by Joy Kogawa, Naomi learns that her mother survived the atomic bombing of Nagasaki after she reads letters that belong to her Aunt Emily.

answers: Wyeth [accept Andrew Wyeth or Andrew Newell Wyeth; accept Jamie Wyeth or Jamie Browning Wyeth]
Christina [or Anna Christina Olson or Christina Olson; accept Christina’s World]
Maine [or ME]
parts: Give this surname. The massive painting Portrait of Pig is by an artist with this surname, who painted a striking self-portrait of himself with a pumpkin for a head.

The composition of the aforementioned painting, Winter, 1946, is similar to another Andrew Wyeth painting titled for this woman’s "World," in which she looks up a field toward a house. Her common first name is acceptable.

The hill depicted in Christina's World is in this US state. Winslow Homer painted many of his sea paintings while at Prouts Neck on the coast of this state, which Marsden Hartley dubbed himself the “painter of.”

answers: Gothic script [or blackletter; or Gothic minuscule; or Textura or Textualis; or broken script or gebrochenen Schriften; accept Gothic fiction or Gothic novels or Gothic horror]
Fraktur [accept Antiqua–Fraktur dispute]

Futura [accept Futura Bold Oblique or Futura Black or Futura Inline or Futura Condensed or Futura Demibold or Futura Display or Futura Schlagzeile or Steile Futura] (Supreme’s use of Futura was likely directly lifted from Kruger’s art.)
parts: Name these typefaces derived from Carolingian minuscule. Newspaper mastheads and “Ye Olde” shops often use this faux-Old English script, whose common name is also given to spooky novels like The Castle of Otranto.

This Gothic blackletter typeface remained ubiquitous in German printing until the late 19th century. Although Neo-Nazis often telegraph their ideology by using this typeface, Hitler actually banned it in favor of Antiqua fonts.

Paul Renner created this geometric sans-serif typeface as a modern alternative to Fraktur. This typeface appears in the Supreme logo, Barbara Kruger’s art, Wes Anderson films, and Vampire Weekend album covers.

answers: Pagan Kingdom [or Pagan Empire or Pagan dynasty; or Bagan Kingdom or Bagankhit]

Angkor [accept Angkor Wat; accept Angkor Thom, accept Yaśōdharapura or Yasodharapura or Yea-sau-da-rea-puor]
parts: Name this kingdom founded by Anawhrata. Immigrants from the Kingdom of Nánzhào (“non-jow”) founded this kingdom, which absorbed the Pyu city-states.
The Burmese Pagan Kingdom eventually fell to this dynasty of China. The founder of this Mongol dynasty, Kublai Khan, invaded Pagan after its rulers refused to pay tribute.

A Siamese chronicle claims that Anawhrata sacked this capital city of a neighboring empire, forcing it to pay tribute to the Pagan Kingdom. This city contains the large West Baray and a temple modeled on Mount Meru.

“Rappaccini’s Daughter”
parts: Name this character who learns at the end of that story to avoid a “delirium... more transient than that of wine” even if it “were for years instead of moments.” This character causes three men to vie for the affection of a widow.
This author of “Dr. Heidegger’s Experiment” also wrote about the cold-hearted physician Roger Chillingworth in his novel The Scarlet Letter.
The title character of this Hawthorne story tends to the poisonous garden maintained by her botanist father, which gives her a “fatal breath” that withers flowers and kills insects.

answers: angels [or elohim; or malak; accept archangels]
Book of Enoch [accept 1 Enoch]
Uriel [or Auriel; or Oriel]
parts: Name these heavenly beings from Abrahamic mythology. Cherubim and seraphim are two classes of these winged beings.

A major source of angelology is this apocryphal book of the Bible, which describes the fall of angels known as the “watchers.” This book is named for a great-grandfather of Noah who “walked with God.”

In the Book of Enoch, the fallen angels are judged by this archangel along with Michael, Raphael, and Gabriel. Either this archangel or Jophiel used a flaming sword to guard the Garden of Eden after the Fall.

answers: polarization [or word forms such as polarized]
Brewster’s angle
cosine squared [accept one plus cosine of two theta over two]
parts: Name this property of light that describes the direction in which its electric field oscillates. Lenses that filter light based on this property can be used to reduce glare.
A simple polarizer can be made by tilting a transparent plate at this angle to incoming light. Light that is reflected at this angle becomes completely polarized.

The intensity of polarized light passing through an ideal polarizer is multiplied by this function of the angle between their orientations. Polarizers cut unpolarized light’s intensity in half because this function’s average value is one half.

parts: Name this property that generally makes optimization problems easier, since it implies that any local minimum is necessarily a global minimum. A function has this property if its secant lines always lie above its tangent lines.
In one dimension, unconstrained optimization of a convex function f can be solved by setting this operation of f equal to zero. This operation gives the infinitesimal rate of change of a function.

Consider the constrained optimization problem: [read slowly] “maximize f of x subject to g of x equals zero.” In one dimension, the method of Lagrange multipliers sets f-prime of x equal to the product of what two quantities?
